text: I decided to become an entrepreneur
instead of taking a more traditional
path when I graduated from Stanford and
was headed back to Stanford Law School I
ran into a friend of mine who was
graduating from Stanford Business School
and he decided that after a career
Investment Banking before Business
School he was going to start a
restaurant company and to the chagrin
and consternation and fear of my parents
I decided to bail on Stanford Law School
two days before it started and become an
entrepreneur who ended up running those
restaurants we grew it to 20 million in
sales and then sold the company and I
was sold I went back to Harvard Business
School with the intention of
transitioning into something that was
more sustainable and something that was
more interesting to me which was
healthcare and I have been in
entrepreneurial environment since then
as the head of these small companies
that we try and grow to be bigger
companies for me entrepreneurs and
entrepreneurship is balancing risk and
reward and risk is the scariest part the
idea of launching into something that is
unknown is hard to do there's a certain
mindset that's associated with being
able to take that risk and there is a
certain amount of preparation that needs
to be done in order to have confidence
to take that risk
entrepreneurship is learned it's not
it's not innate you learn how to be a
good entrepreneur like you learn how to
be a good bike rider or you learn how to
be a good cook and what I offer students
is the ability to get confidence in
skillsets to understand where they need
to focus and push and where they they
potentially face pitfalls to give them
the confidence to jump in and become
entrepreneurs
you
